reviewText:
This interactive story is very engaging. The plot is elusive, but not for lack of substance, but rather a poetic metering of details. The delivery of the story focuses on imagery and character interaction, and to some extent on the characters themselves. Very abstract, but it really gets to you. I live right in the middle of the setting of the game, and the overmap represents the region very well (in an abstract way, it is not a true map but the regions are as familiar as home). This makes the descriptions of the different truck stops much more immediate to me, but they are well-crafted on their own.

I'm a big fan of this game, definitely recommend it.

I finished playing Act III. The mood of this game is so intense! I'm somewhere between 'deeply unsettled' and 'terrified'. I absolutely recommend playing the free interquels you can find on the developer's site kentuckyroutezero.com . They add context to the game's plot and characters, but The Entertainment especially is also a very interesting experience on its own.

I know some people have complaints about the slow development schedule, but Cardboard Computer isn't a big dev like Telltale. A game that I'm so enthralled with like Zero is hard to wait for, but Act III blew me away and I'm willing to wait for that kind of quality.

The third interquel came out recently and it is just as avant-garde as the second. It takes the form of a phone number, and has already revealed many secrets. It even inspired me to take a trip to my local state park.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I don't really know how to describe this game except that it probably isn't quite what you're expecting, in a good way. I believe it's been classified as an interactive narrative rather than a game. Interaction is based around moving the main character within the scenes and opening dialogue with others. The dialogue will change based on which response you choose, however you cannot truly alter the outcomes of each segment.

The strong points within this story are the art direction and audio by far, it's quite fantastic. I feel the largest drawback with this game as it continues development is the absence of puzzles, even simple ones. I think there was just one in the very beginning, you had to retrieve an item for an old man. This allowed interaction between the main character and the environment, which is almost completely missing now.

I can't really describe the experience of this, for most I suspect it will mystify and be quite eerie....maybe even sad at points. I enjoy that it's designed that way because there are so few games or interactive narratives that are. If you were to ask me what to expect from this, I don't know what to say....you're in for a great surprise.

reviewText: Kentucky Route Zero trancends it's genre, it's not just a Point & Click game, it is an experience. The atmosphere provides a stark and beautiful backdrop for the narrative. The adventure on which you embark is in itself both dreamlike and nightmareish making it hard to stop playing once you've taken the plunge. Not only is this an amazing game and a step that shows us that narrative gameplay is a viable option but it also shows us that episodic gameplay works as well. reviewText:
What is Kentucky Route Zero? I'm not sure. It's not exactly a game... as far as I know the player does not have any agency whatsoever. There's no inventory. There are no Sierra death screens. In fact, not much really *happens* in the game: it takes place on a summer night in rural Kentucky.

Well, that's a lie. It takes place in some kind of Kentucky not at all like the real Kentucky. It's a Kentucky that I really, sorely wish I could visit, because this place is amazing. Everything about this world is something you can get lost in. It's as real as real can be, but *magical* at the same time. Neil Gaiman kinda stuff. It's probably the most aesthetically complete game I've ever played, and there's clearly a lot of love poured into its art and sound design. The music, especially, is top notch.

You want to play this game, or story, or whatever the hell it is. Just buy it.

reviewText:
Kentucky Route Zero is a weird and wonderful point-and-click adventure game that will leave you thinking long after you've stopped playing. Its unique and iconic art direction, coupled with a narrative that is intriguing and fresh, makes it a game unlike any other.

Like To the Moon, and like Thirty Flights of Loving, Kentucky Route Zero places significant emphasis on plot and storytelling, and the result is a first act that leaves the player reflecting on all the surreal events that just happened and what they mean. Questions of reality and subjectivity are posed by the game, and the one thing the player can conclude at the end of Act I is that there are no hard and fast answers to them; at least, there are none that present themselves within this act. There isn't much in the way of actual gameplay either, although the point-and-click elements play a large role in fleshing out the character of Conrad; the story is told mainly from his point of view.

Kentucky Route Zero is not for everyone; that much is certain. Its strange narrative, point-and-click mechanics and lack of any sort of traditional gameplay makes it appear intimidating at first glance. Yet the game is so well-made, with such detail in its presentation and sound design, that it proves impossible not to be swept up in its magical, surreal tale. If you have any interest at all in games as a narrative medium, you owe it to yourself to play Kentucky Route Zero.

reviewText: I played the first act of Kentucky Route Zero this afternoon and it put me in a really nice mood.  It's got a nice leisurely pace and encourages the player to be inquisitive without having to exhaustively check every nook and cranny or click every dialogue option.  The spectacular vector art, subtle audio, and ambiguous writing keep the game half on-screen and half in the player's head.  The main gameplay is mostly just moving the character around the screen and reading dialog and descriptions, so this isn't a game for everybody, but it's exactly the type of thing I'd like to see more of.  I'm really looking forward to the rest of this as it comes out.

reviewText:
Kentucky Route Zero is a beautiful, understated adventure game that should not be ignored. Throughout the first two chapters (those that are released now) there is a range of imagery that is hauntingly beautiful. Seriously, the art direction in KRZ is something that should be noted by game designers everywhere. Thinking back there are some vistas that still pull an emotional response out of me weeks after playing the game.

As for gameplay, the overly cumbersome adventure game machinations have thankfully been left out of KRZ. There are no ridiculous item-combining puzzles to slog through, and no detailed logbooks to track lengthy bait and switch quests. KRZ welcomes you in with its stunning atmosphere, and leaves you to your need to explore. The game subtly bends its lore to your will, through dialogue choices that rewrite certain details of the world you are exploring.

When all put together, there are only a few hours of gameplay in the package right now. I eagerly await coming chapters, but it may be steep for anyone who is unsure if the game sounds right for them. However, if you are a fan of adventure games, indie games that dare to do something different or just plain want to be enthralled by an experience, buy in now.

reviewText:
It's hard to talk about KRZ without spoiling the experience. The experience, however, is second to none. It's short, Act I is about an hour and a half long, and that's what I've played so far plus a brief portion of Act II. The attention to detail is impecable and you'll stumble across something and wonder how it wasn't obvious it was there the entire time. It's a point and click, and it's exploration driven but it's not about exploring the game as much as it is about exploring who you are within the game.

Again, it's hard to explain about spoiling the magic, so lets just say the game progresses in a way unlike any other story driven game I've played and it makes you feel not just an observer of the game, but an integral part of the story. This is one of the rare titles that has been around for a while but the deepest I've seen it discounted is 50% and that alone intrigued me to pick it up without knowing more than it's critically aclaimed. Up to this point I can say I'm not disappointed with my purchase and I can only see it becoming more worth it as the game unfolds.

Finally, this is a game richer than a Godiva Chocolate Cheesecake. You will have to pace yourself :)

reviewText: As a Kentuckian and a patron of the arts, Kentucky Route Zero has quickly become one of my favorite indy games. One part existentialist play, one part art piece, and one part point-and-click adventure, it's incredible how much this one game manages to pack in without being too much to handle. Every part of the game is in-depth and interesting from the conversations, the interactive sets"
date: and the characters themselves. The minimalist art design and the vague
recommended: often melancholy/mysterious dialogue compliment each other perfectly giving the game its signature feel which is really undescribable. Upon multiple playthroughs
hoursPlayed: one finds that the different conversation choices available can drastically change the experience and mood of the game; not from the technical standpoint but more the emotional experience of the player.\nWhile not a fast or necessarily exciting game gameplay-wise
voteText: various types of interesting and fun gameplay are introduced early on and continue throughout the different acts of KRZ. Examples of these gameplay styles being the character-oriented gameplay
helpfulPercent: travel gameplay
votesHelpful: and perhaps the most fascinating of all
votesTotal: traveling on the Zero. These gameplay styles tie into the story which is exciting in its complexity and immersiveness
votesFunny: new sub-plots are constantly introduced keeping the game fresh. The often loose ends of these sub-plots
commentsCount: mentioned briefly perhaps in a passing conversation
column16:
give the characters depth and mystery.
I find myself lost within the world of KRZ every time I play and am almost tempted to drive out on the highways featured within the game (highways I know well) to see if I can find the Zero and explore it myself.
10/10

The additional "mini games" free for download
column17: Limits and Demonstrations and The Entertainment
column18: are both equally as intriguing as KRZ itself. While very fast to play
column19: they provide small pieces of possibly important exposition which can be found referenced within KRZ if the player pays attention. The blending of storytelling throughout various games/time periods is genius. Both of these free games contain the same gameplay mechanics of KRZ so they are easy to jump right into after playing the main game. Definitely worth downloading and playing if you have a few minutes and want to expand your knowledge of the KRZ universe.\nThe script for The Entertainment is available for purchase in paperback for a very low price. I bought it and love having a piece of the KRZ universe that I can hold in my hands and read. Really fascinating."

reviewText: Kentucky Route Zero inspires an amazing, surreal feeling better than any game I've ever played. Driving around at night is a truly magical yet minimalistic experience. But the production, and in particular the sound design is absolutely incredible. There's some particularly amazing sound design in the mines in the first act, and then while driving in the second act. Also, the old folk songs played by silhouettes invoke an around-the-campfire ambience.\n\nIncredible game, through and through. Cannot recommend more.

reviewText:
I literally cried while playing this game.

It sets a bar for storytelling and creativity so far out of my reach that I openly wept in front of my monitor.

When I pulled my self together, I resolved to do something - anything - that could give other people the feelings that this game evoked in me. Frankly, I'm terrified to finish KR0.

Games as thoughtful as this don't come often - 'thoughtful' to gameplay design, plot, visuals, etc. KR0 is an aberration.

reviewText:
I will give this game a guarded recommendation, because although I like it (so far) it seems like way too long between chapters.

Kentucky Route Zero is beautiful, surreal, moody, and atmospheric to the max.  More a story than a game, it's about exploration and thoughtful consideration of events as they unfold. Creepy moments serve to keep you interested, which is important because there are no puzzles, no conflict and only the barest thread of a narrative. That means it's not everybody's cup of tea.

The only tension is whether your decisions and dialogue choices have really made any difference. For example, I think one of my decisions caused my character to develop a limp when he otherwise might not have. Who knows, I'll have to play it again.

So to sum up: beautiful game/story, not for everyone, well worth the sale price, concerned how long between chapters.

reviewText: Kentucky Route Zero has the best use of atmopshere I've ever seen in a game. While most of the time atmosphere in games is equated to spoopy dark hallways"
recommended: washed out colors and wide camera angles to make its world seem desolate and distant.\n\nThis aesthetic lends a lot of emotional weight to the game's story about the mudane lives of people dealing with poverty. The writing is excellent
hoursPlayed: especially that of the dialogue. All of the conversation is very mellow
voteText: but hints very effectively at the unsaid ways the characters feel. The dialogue trees are also done excellently. They're not about checking off little variables and affecting the game later
helpfulPercent: they allow you to make little decisions about what kind of people the characters are. It's more like being a part of the storytelling than choosing a path.\n\nUnlike many other "story-focused games"
votesHelpful: KY0 has a sense of brevity. The pacing is excellent
votesTotal: 3 hours went by faster than a couple minutes of RPG exposition. Nothing feels cliche and every line is well-thought out. I don't think I've ever seen a game be more poigniant.\n\nThis is usually where I'd say that you shouldn't get this is you're looking for a traditional game
votesFunny: but that's not true. You should at least try it

column16: though. As of writing the game is on sale for $12.50

column18: and there's no guarantee the next 3 will maintain this level of quality. Still

reviewText: In this new age of videogames beomcing a realm more and more devoted to content and story, this one stands a testament to the ability of the gaming world to become a powerhouse in both creativity and a medium of expression. Rarely does one find a method of storytelling as intricate and articulate as this one, even within novels or written works, and here in Kentucky Route Zero I believe we have found a masterpiece in the art of world construction. Not only does it play off of the decisions one makes, but it also leaves room for the player to wonder what exactly they missed. The game, I feel, is not so much drawn on by what one does, but what one might have missed. A stunning work of creative non-ficiton in gaming form. Let there be more works like this to recreate the image of gaming at large, drawing the stereotype away from violence and chaotic, negative influences, and towards the infinite possibilities of both art creativity that game design creates.

reviewText: From the very start, Kentucky Route Zero runs cirlces around every other attempt at video game storytelling. The release of Act 3 is an incredibly powerful reminder that when it comes to interactive narrative, Cardboard Computer is absolutely without peer. KRZ is beautiful, quiet, haunting, tragic, and incredibly resonant. I guarantee that there's nothing your game collection that's quite like it. I don't even want to delve into the details of the game, because it's a work that deserves to be experienced completely fresh. I guess what I'm trying to say here is that there are Kentucky Route Zero reasons why you shouldn't buy this game.

reviewText: Sometimes when you're flying through space you end up meeting a robot. Sometimes that robot is wearing a dress and rides a motorcycle with another robot. Sometimes that robot plays the keytar and likes to sing in dive bars. Sometimes that robot knows the entire history and future of the world in which you live. Sometimes that robot is Lieutenant Commander Data. These scientificially observed facts are called Scalzi's laws of robotics. A robot can only be one of those four things. Kentucky Route Zero is a game that explores what it might mean for the laws of robotics to be slightly relaxed (not unlike how Star Trek slightly relaxes the intergalactic speed limit), allowing a robot to be multiple types of robot at the same time. That's right, in Kentucky Route Zero, Lieutenant Commander Data puts on a dress, picks up a keytar and plans your destiny from his dive bar. This is a wonderful game that really makes you think about the universe and doesn't contain any disturbing skeletons.

reviewText:
I'll be honest; I have no ♥♥♥♥ing idea what is happening in this game at any point in time. Apparently, it has something to do with Amercian folklore, of which I am completely unfamiliar and so I am concerned that the point of this game has gone over my head. Besides the inexplicable strangeness and confounding quality of the game, it has very interesting 2 1/2 D graphics and an awesome soundtrack that create a unique and very stylish atmosphere in the game.

Bear in mind that, even though I was lost and understood the game as much as I would Algebra equations explained by handwritten notes in Mandarin, it was entertaining and gripping the whole time. Not in a thrilling/jumping out of your seat way, but it may pique your curiosity and inspire you to wonder whether you are experiencing exposition or subtext. Another player mentioned that this game could have been made by David Lynch, and I'm inclined to agree that it reminds me a lot of Blue Velvet.

Incredibly weird and confusing, yet strangely charming and atmospheric. ****

reviewText:
It's strange how sometimes playing a game relates so deeply with your current situation that it feels as though it was made specifically for you at that moment. You get a pit in your stomach and when you stop playing you see the world in a whole new light. Perspective changes and you just feel as though a weight has been lifted off of you when you turn your attention away from the screen after that last pivotal plot point.

Personally I am going through an extended transition from previous Military experience, then school, and now a professional career with a family, life can be pretty confusing. That confusion has nothing on Kentucky Route Zero by developer Cardboard Computer. There are words that can describe the game: surreal, strange, odd, uncanny, bizarre. You can describe the things that happen in the story by sequence, but completing the ideas as to how or why these things happen is impossible.

The game itself isn't so much a game as a series of events that captures you and allows you to shape the adventure and it's contents as a concept of your own design. The events are all going to happen regardless of whether or not you make certain choices, the only thing that may change are dialogue options and responses. You even begin to have conversations with yourself through multiple characters gradually. This is interesting because now both sides of the conversation have different possibilities, and somehow the conversations seem less mechanical even if they are with yourself.

Going back to describing the game, there are words to describe it, but each of those words seem to have connotations that don't fully encompass the ideas portrayed. The feeling is fuller, than those words can describe. It's very odd, and I don't want to give any of it away as a spoiler.

Things that are strange and unbelievable happen and the characters seem to take it with a grain of salt. Things like traveling on an inter-dimensional highway with arbitrary markers made of everyday items, replacing a leg with a metal skeleton prosthesis (and not reacting), taking a shot with a skeleton with a tape recorder, flying on a giant eagle that moves houses daily. These are all taken by the characters as something completely acceptable if a bit odd. No explanation of why these things are happening, just that they do.



There is no time or place to explore why these things happen, so taking them with stride is forced on the player as well as the characters. You can only move forward and there are no places to take breaks to look for answers. So you derive the answers from events as they move along, and accept what doesn't make sense, and just move along. Eventually events in the story that didn't make sense are after the fact, and become a part of the plot. So even surreal happenings can become important regardless of how illogical or insane they seem at first.

The entire interface is a point and click adventure, but there are only so many things you can point and click on and they are all labeled for convenience and to keep the story moving at a reasonable pace. This doesn't detract from the experience, as the game itself is surreal enough to keep you entertained. If anything it keeps things interesting as you always want to move forward to see what strange happenings are next.

The strange is the spectacle. And the glass through which you look is your own mind. The experience is engrossing.

You'll like this game if: You enjoy M.C. Escher and Picasso, and want to play a game designed by them. Strictly for those though that enjoy being told a story, and not necessarily molding it.

My review blog where I review games that I play from my steam library is here: http://bigdadgamer.blogspot.com/

reviewText: I'm not all too familiar with point-and-click games or stories steeped in magical realism, but Kentucky Route Zero is both, and has made me a fan. A bit highbrow and downright esoteric, KRZ isn't for everyone yet still manages to be enjoyable to most--a bit like Journey (thatgamecompany / PS3), in the sense that its story eludes simple or quick understanding. But also like Journey and other similarly abstruse titles, it's easy to sink into KRZ even if just for the cozy moodiness and particularly the pleasantly haunting soundtrack which draws strongly from old bluegrass tunes.

reviewText: I played the first act of Kentucky Route Zero this afternoon and it put me in a really nice mood.  It's got a nice leisurely pace and encourages the player to be inquisitive without having to exhaustively check every nook and cranny or click every dialogue option.  The spectacular vector art, subtle audio, and ambiguous writing keep the game half on-screen and half in the player's head.  The main gameplay is mostly just moving the character around the screen and reading dialog and descriptions, so this isn't a game for everybody, but it's exactly the type of thing I'd like to see more of.  I'm really looking forward to the rest of this as it comes out.

reviewText:
Kentucky Route Zero is a beautiful, understated adventure game that should not be ignored. Throughout the first two chapters (those that are released now) there is a range of imagery that is hauntingly beautiful. Seriously, the art direction in KRZ is something that should be noted by game designers everywhere. Thinking back there are some vistas that still pull an emotional response out of me weeks after playing the game.

As for gameplay, the overly cumbersome adventure game machinations have thankfully been left out of KRZ. There are no ridiculous item-combining puzzles to slog through, and no detailed logbooks to track lengthy bait and switch quests. KRZ welcomes you in with its stunning atmosphere, and leaves you to your need to explore. The game subtly bends its lore to your will, through dialogue choices that rewrite certain details of the world you are exploring.

When all put together, there are only a few hours of gameplay in the package right now. I eagerly await coming chapters, but it may be steep for anyone who is unsure if the game sounds right for them. However, if you are a fan of adventure games, indie games that dare to do something different or just plain want to be enthralled by an experience, buy in now.

reviewText:
[Updated for Act II]

This game is really hard to define.

An artwork in the subtle, the surreal, the atmopsheric, the experimental.

An audio visual experience. An interactive narrative. A stylized point n click adventure.

It's slow paced. There's no voice acting. It's minimalistic but beautiful.

reviewText: Two acts and two intermissions with more episodes to come in 2014, but an incomplete package manages to take my top spot this year. Kentucky Route Zero creates one of the most unique, ethereal, dream-like and inspirational games I’ve ever played. Every scene is so totally mind-bending, atmospheric, filled with wonder and encapsulates what games as a medium are capable of doing. Jake and Tamas at Cardboard Computer might be extra-dimensional creatures pulling new concepts from another time and place. And if so, I love them for it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I picked up this game because I found the concept rather intriguing.  A secret highway under Kentucky?  I wasn't sure what to expect but I figured what the heck.

The world of Kentucky Route Zero is beautiful and mysterious, full of odd characters and dark, derelict places.  The dialogue is all in text form and that seems to help the ambience.  The gameplay is point and click like the old adventure games however there is not much beyond that.  There are no puzzles to solve or minigames as far as I can tell.  It boils down to an interactive story, albeit one that is told very well.

Overall I am torn about this.  The art and music are wonderful but the gameplay itself is very shallow.  If the price is right it might be worth checking out.
